reviewText: I've always enjoyed this program and it can be seen on tv quite often. It traces the history of wrestling from the cavemen till about 1999. There is various clips from both WCW and WWF with wrestlers from each company talk about the past and present. While neither company slam one anther, it's still very well done. If you enjoy wrestling then i'd recommend this dvd. If you want the rough side of wrestling i'd pick up Beyond the Mat.
summary: The Unreal Story of Pro Wrestling (900th review)
Title: N/A

reviewText: Honestly, if you are looking for a wrestling documentary, if you don't already have it, I would highly suggest getting Beyond The Mat before buying this one, as Beyond The Mat is a much better, much deeper look into the world of professional wrestling. If you already have or have seen Beyond The Mat, this DVD would be an excellent add to your collection. This documentary originally aired on A&E, and is presented in a manner to explain pro wrestling to the non-wrestling fan. For wrestling collectors, this is a must have. For the casual fan, go with Beyond The Mat instead.
summary: One Of The Best Wrestling Documentaries Avalible.
Title: N/A

reviewText: this is an excellent A&E documenatary presented by Steve Allen.  the dvd starts from the beginning, discussing the history of wrestling and the traveling circuits it made.  it continues through the history of television and how that media changed the wrestling world.  there are many b&w clips of the old wrestlers and matches.  and the quality is very good.  the history continues right up to modern day and vince mcmahon's empire.  this along with Beyond the Mat, should give one a fairly good picture of the history of wrestling.  as an extra, you get a fun trivia test and if you miss a question, you get booed!  highly recommended (and inexpensive) for fans of the sport!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I saw this premiere on A&E the night before the April 27, 1998, WWF Raw is War/War Zone show from Hampton, Virginia (which I attended). That date is very significant because it was the moment, in my opinion, that the WWF started to soar in mainstream popularity once again.This documentary premiered the night before that fateful show. It served as a prelude of what was to come over the next couple of years. Basically, it is a pretty-much thorough history of professional wrestling in the United States, from Frank Gotch and George Hackenschmidt to Shawn Michaels and Stone Cold Steve Austin.Although the most recent stuff that is covered is from October 1997 - just before Bill Goldberg started his meteoric rise to fame and right before the double-cross in Montreal - the documentary is still contemporary enough that you can still relate to it in the present terms.There are few inaccuracies in this documentary. Pretty much everything is spot-on, history-wise.I still give it a very high recommendation. If you wish to delve into the history of the grand spectacle of pro wrestling, this is a great place to start.
summary: Not very timely, but still a good contemporary documentary
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really enjoyed the unreal story of pro wrestling. It was a thorough description about pro wrestling, its roots and important moments. If you enjoy wrestling you are going to enjoy that movie. The only hiccup I can think about is that it spends a little too much of time talking about the birth of wrestling but then again, it is a documentary.
Title: N/A
